subject: Math
title: Introduction to Quadratic Functions
description: Learn what makes a function quadratic and identify quadratic functions

content.text: A quadratic function is a polynomial function with a degree of 2. They create U-shaped curves called parabolas and appear everywhere in physics, engineering, and real life!

content.heading: General Form of a Quadratic
content.text: A quadratic function has the form: f(x) = ax² + bx + c, where a ≠ 0. The highest power of x is 2, and 'a', 'b', and 'c' are constants.

content.heading: Key Features
content.text:
• If a > 0, the parabola opens upward (U-shape)
• If a < 0, the parabola opens downward (∩-shape)
• The coefficient 'a' affects how wide or narrow the parabola is
• 'c' is the y-intercept

content.heading: Example 1
solution: Check the highest power of x: it's 2
Check that the coefficient of x² is not zero: a = 3 ≠ 0
Yes, this is a quadratic function!

content.heading: Example 2
content.problem: Identify a, b, and c in f(x) = -2x² + 7x - 1
solution: Since a < 0, this parabola opens downward

content.heading: Practice Problems
problems: Is g(x) = 2x³ + x² - 4 a quadratic function? (yes/no)
In f(x) = 4x² - 8x + 3, what is the value of a?
In f(x) = -x² + 5x - 2, what is the value of b?
In f(x) = 3x² - 7, what is the value of c?
Does f(x) = 6x² - 4x + 1 open upward or downward?
Does f(x) = -5x² + 2x - 3 open upward or downward?
What is the y-intercept of f(x) = 2x² + 3x - 5?
In f(x) = -3x² + x, what is c?
